description:
This place is such a dive bar, in the best way possible.  We had a hotel room just down the street, and were in need of a cocktail.  I found this place on Yelp, being really close to us so we went in.

It's dark, and looks like a pretty fun place to hang at night. Pool table, darts. The drinks were not overly priced, and the bar tender was pretty friendly.

Pretty great location, as it's the only bar around.  I dug it!
author: Michelle H.

description: Just your average hole in the wall bar. Bar tender not too talkative and not sure he completely knows what he is doing. I ordered a kamikaze and got a vodka cranberry instead. Strong drink just not what I wanted. They have pool, a pinball machine, and darts. Props for being conveniently downstairs the Beach motel; so, if you are ever staying at the Beach motel and you need to wet your whistle but are not trying to travel this place is pretty convenient.
author: Mariana H.

description:
I had a long day on the beach and just wanted a beer. Not at a touristy spot I wanted something different.
I came to this awesome dive bar and met the bartender Bob who was super down to earth. I also met with some of the locals and chatted with them. Older crowd which I didn't mind one bit. Everyone's super friendly!
Legit dive bar if you are trying to get off the beaten path.
author: Estella I.

description:
reminds me of a locals bar from the Midwest!
Kelly is great

parking can be an issue
author: C J.

description:
This is the first local dive bar I've visited since moving to the Outer Sunset, and it was quite a warm and welcoming experience! My roommate took me here one Monday evening. We took our seats at the bar and ordered drinks from the friendly bartender. One of the regulars came over to the bar to get a drink, and we ended up chatting with him about the neighborhood. What a great conversation. Super chill.

This isn't the kind of bar you would trek across the city for, but if you live nearby, this is a great watering hole for locals. I'll definitely be coming back more frequently, enjoying the company and maybe even the pinball machine and pool table that's here.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Hands down the best bar in the city! Even if you aren't a Pittsburgh fan it's an awesome place to get cheap drinks and have a good convo :)

Dan and the rest of his staff are so nice and always willing to put your sports team on one of the TVs. 

However, this IS the best place to watch all Pittsburgh teams year round. You'll be joined by mostly by Pennsylvania locals. 

AND they're dog friendly
author: Megan D.

description:
A decent dive bar in the outer Outer Mission.

There's the N line that runs through that was kind of noisy at first, but you get used to it after drinking a little bit. Maybe it's sensory deprivation or just getting a little tipsy...

Anyway, the drinks were affordable.

There's two pool tables and a pinball machine.

My only concern was the men's bathroom was really cramped. There's a urinal in the corner and if you gotta use the toilet, you have to squeeze in super closely to that person using the urinal...

Other than that, my boyfriend and I may come here again!
author: Aj C.

description:
The bar itself is a 4-star but the patrons here can get weird. I came here on a Friday night and many of the people here look like they are from the park and they look either wasted or they are on meth.

The bartender is great though. She can handle these odd guests just fine while taking good care of everyone sitting at the bar.
author: Joseph L.

description:
I'll be honest - my visits have been largely opportunistic for other purposes.  This little watering-hole is out at the edge of the universe (Ocean Beach at the end of the N-Judah).  It's several thousand more miles West until you'll hit another dive bar.  After many a trek out to Ocean Beach, Golden Gate Park, etc. this has been a good stop to A) Use the bathroom before catching the Muni back, B) Charge my phone after taking lots of photos, and C) Have a few beers, because, why not?  

To be fair, there's not a lot of options out in this neck of the woods.  Before I had visited here, my impression was that it was sorta sketchy.  That hasn't been my impression now that I've visited.  It seems like a neighborhood place with a core of regulars - and I've had a few interesting conversations (and learned all sorts of cool stuff - like why Judah is called Judah).  Generally the crowd is a little on the older side.  I've seen a lot of negative comments about the service on Yelp, but I can't say that I've had any complaints.  It's about what I would expect.   They've got plenty of space, and have two pool tables, so it's not a bad place to chill.  And, they have a Pittsburgh connection.  

Are you going to find a designer cocktail list here?  No.  Are you getting dolled-up on Friday night and come here?  No.  But, if you'd like a solid place to grab a quick drink, check it out.  

(***Side Note - and I'm not 100% sure this is correct - But, I was told that they have a family connection to David Evans Strickler, the guy who invented the Banana Split in Latrobe, Pennsylvania.***)
author: Adam S.

description:
Came in today while I was waiting for an appointment. Taps were broken or unusable for whatever reason,  and bottles were a small selection. (Mostly bud and coors)

 Don't know if I'll come back and try them again on a different day.
author: Javene R.

description: This is my favorite bar in San Francisco. Why? Because it is a *real* dive bar - not a hipster wannabe divebar that overcharges for drinks and is overrun with tech bros. It's a no-frills local watering hole that has held on to it's divey glory even through the tech boom, and as a Pittsburgh native, I can tell ya it really feels like Pittsburgh inside, complete with awesome memorabilia and the blue-collar charm.
author: Emily S.

description:
An unapologetic dive. 
What you see is what you get. 
And therein lies the charm that is Pittsburgh's Pub.

It's a non-nonsense, "what are you having" kind of bar with functional service from the bartender with minimal fuss. Standard beers on tap and they do a decent bloody Mary here. It's just one of those bars that has stood the test of time with little to no change over the years it seems. And it's charming. If you're a fan of unpretentious dives, local watering holes, or you're a Pittsburgh fan, this is a good spot for you. 

Worth a stop in if you're out by Ocean Beach on a weekend. Stop in for a morning boozy start and you'll probably have fun conversations with local regulars beginning their day too. Nothing fancy, but still much fun.
author: Jon L.

description:
Whoever works in the mornings (a woman) who answers the phones is rude as hell. I left a pair of sunglasses there and when I called the next day to ask if it was there, she checked and then said, "don't have it" and hung up.

Really? Is that necessary? 

Is this bad review really necessary? For rude ass workers who treat paying customers like that, yes... it is.
author: CT T.

description:
Well, I am biased. I lived around the corner (more or less) for more than 10 years and it was (and in some ways still is) my neighborhood watering hole.

All in all, I've never taken anyone here that did not have a good time. This is it, the real thing, a San Francisco bar that caters to the locals, who after all, pay their rent. That being said, visitors are always welcome, and warmly accepted by the staff and regulars.

Bottom line, well poured drinks and good prices. Good and prompt service with a friendly attitude, provided you are friendly as well.

Hints? This is strictly cash only, although last time I checked they do have an ATM on premises. And, please leave your puscafe and blended daiquiri orders at the door. Not that the bartenders will not make them, I just have too much respect for the owner and staff to put them though all that trouble.

Long and the short? They serve drinks in the fashion of "Nick's Place" with the neighborhood attitude of "Martini's." (And, if you don't know the reference, rent "It's A Wonderful Life."

Oh, and the "atmosphere" of this place varies by time of day, so if you do not like it the first time, try a different day or time. The variety will amaze you.
author: Bruce L.

description:
I have been to Pittsburgh's Pub many times. It is a standard neighborhood bar nestled at the end of the Judah line right next to Ocean Beach. You can get cold drinks and a game of pool while waiting for the next train or after a long day at the beach. The place is a true dive bar, but that is not a bad thing. They have a great draught beer selection and plenty of hard stuff for chasing.

One of the unique things is the extensive Pittsburgh sports memorabilia. This would be a great place for a Steelers or Penguins fan to catch a game. I would love to see the owners face when they play the 49ers or Sharks though!
author: Kristian D.

description: Solid bar. Standard stock of beer. 2 pinball machines, 2 pool tables with decent cues. Great neighborhood bar tucked in the backside of the sunset. Crowd is always awesome. Mostly on the younger side with a few older folks. Super chill. I love coming here to pick pool games with random people. Cash only
author: Elton F.

description:
Friendly bartender. Perfect dive bar. Exactly what you expect from a dive bar, where you expect. And how. 

Booze - tasty
Ambiance - nil
Service - perfect

Will most certainly be back!
author: Peter S.

description:
Small neighborhood dive bar. 

Pros:
Pool tables and pinball
This was the only bar within a couple miles that had the Stanley Cup on TV
Dog Friendly
Cheap drinks 
No nonsense bartender

Cons:
No nonsense bartender
Poor beer selection

Summary:
Classic dive bar
Seems like they cater to locals
author: Ben S.

description:
Pitts is the old drinking hole all the way down on Judah Street that receives all walks of life. I've even come here at 11 am on a Tuesday and there was an old rowdy crowd drinking at the bar. The owner is really sweet and always gives us a free game of pool. 

I've noticed more of a younger crowd coming through here recently which makes this dull looking bar a bit more vibrant. This area is becoming pretty popular and a lot of newbies to the area I've met here are really cool. If you want to meet different people, Pittsburghs is the place.
author: Anastasia P.

description: This is one crazy fun place. Kelly is a real hoot. Just an all around fun place to hang.
author: Colleen A.

description:
First I love this place. Definitely my first pick for this neighborhood.

However I write this review because 
THEY REALLY NEED TO CLEAN THEIR DRAFT SYSTEM!!!

Hoping they see this, because I love draft beer but not when I can taste the same weird bitter after taste in each beer.

Still love this place just not gonna order a beer till its fixed. 

Hope you guys see this, once it's fixed I'll make this a more happy review
author: Dustin D.

description: Our awesome, friendly, reasonably priced local bar. We love popping in on the weekend - would recommend to anyone in the area.
author: Fi M.

description: Ok this is my first review on my first night moving to SF. This is clearly a working class neighborhood bar. It's monday night at 7pm, there are 5 people in here and not one of then should be operating a vehicle or heavy equipment right now... it smells like an old bar but then if you wanted a cheap drink ducking in from the cold this place genuinely feels welcoming enough. I just moved in nearby so I'm sure I'll check in from here again and make sure to update.
author: Matt W.

description: Not much of a Steelers bar.  We traveled out to the outer Sunset hoping for a good Steelers bar, but place emphasizes being a dive over sports or Pittsburgh.  A true dive bar with no credit cards, horrible stinking urinal that barely flushes, and an indifferent owner who's stingy with even soda water.  There were about a dozen Steelers fans.  For a better experience, next time I will try the Steelers-oriented bar in the Mission.
author: T R.

description:
Pool tables, pinball machibes, dart boards, 10 beer taps and old regulars.  Plenty of free street parking.  Strong pours and frendly customers and bartenders.

This is a great place to meet people who will tell you how it was "back in the day."  I find myself drinking here when I'm doing my laundry down the street.
author: Theron L.

description: If you go there Monday through Thursday during lunch time and the lady behind the bar is grumpy, be nice to her. She's my mom and she is an amazing woman and a fixture in the Sunset dive bar world. If you're a regular customer and can't get home for Thanksgiving, she will feed you free of charge! She's an awesome cook so you'll have a happy tummy. Don't let her gruff exterior fool you, she's as sweet as candy. Don't be a jerk or a cheap tipper and she will take care of you. Just tell Geri that Jamie sent you.
author: Jamie B.

description: This place is awesome to grab a cold beer after a warm day at Ocean Beach.  It's a short 10 minute walk...be careful or you will walk right by it! Seems like a locals only spot but they are always welcoming.  Even got a bowl of pretzels the last time...I always stop in on my way to catch the N-Train, great dive bar!
author: K H.

description:
Ms. Kelly is a super friendly bartender. She hooks it up!
It's a chill place to grab a drink with some pals and even converse with some random people. The drinks are pretty darn cheap ($5 for basically any cocktail) is a great deal! 

There are two pool tables and some darts too!

Only gripe I have is CASH ONLY. I don't like bars that are cash only but maybe that's just me
author: Wilson T.

description:
This place barely registers as a dive.  Yes, it is a dive, but we have all been to way worse places.
Acceptable, in that it has booze and pool tables.  Bathrooms not THAT dirty.  once again, i've seen worse.  
at least there is a bar in the outer sunset...
author: Cole M.

description: Ughhh. Jonathan is right. Fights happen a lot here. Its not welcoming at all. Its loud after hours and they have zero respect for their neighbors. Female bartender seems to have a thing going with some of the customers where they prey upon intoxicated customers. Fights and violence seems to be the M.O here.
author: Cliodhna R.

description:
A terrific neighborhood drinking bar. It's the only bar north of Noriega in the Outer Sunset, which is worthy of a star all by itself. But it'd be a great dive in any neighborhood. And it IS a dive. As salty as it may be, everyone's pretty welcoming. So if you can handle some friendly career drinkers, it's a fun spot. And it's open early every day, which is another big plus.

It's also a GREAT pinball bar. Three excellent machines -- Theater of Magic, Attack from Mars, and Fish Tales. They've got some high-def TVs (with only low-def reception), a pool table, and it's dog-friendly.

As with a lot of dives, much of the experience can depend on who's tending bar. There are a few grumpy ones, but usually they're cool. Dan the owner, the tall guy with the mustache and glasses, is behind the bar a lot and is super nice. It's usually a great atmosphere when he's working.

One of my favorite dives in the city. But again, it's probably appropriate for dive bar fans only.
author: kevin a.

description: Does the definition of a dive bar means that the people behind the bar (maybe the owner's?) need to have attitudes? We were near by having brunch and decided to pop in to watch the US vs Portugal game. I had to go to work after the game so couldn't drink. The guy behind the bar had an attitude when we ordered cokes. Why? Don't serve non-alcoholic beverages if you don't want people to order them. When our cokes were done we ordered some more so we were not empty handed. It's a shame really. Would love to go back but I won't and I know they don't care either so we are all good.
author: Claudia B.

description:
It makes me abundantly happy that Pittsburgh's has an overall 4 star reason.

Because what you see at Pittsburgh's -  is what you get.

There's no pretension.

No mean - angry folks.

Just solid drinks. Good people. And...hilarity.

I rarely make it out this far in the Sunset, so  - I was glad, when awhile back  - our friend rallied us for a night of Sunset fun.

The revelry began and ended at Pittsburgh's. 

The characters that we encountered that night were memorable and wonderful. If Pittsburgh's was closer - I would definitely be hanging around here more often. The variety of people in here - is what makes San Francisco such a beautiful place.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: Horrible spot. Fights happen all the time, bartenders are mediocre at best, worst bar i ever been too.
author: Jonathan S.

description: If you're looking for a Pittsburgh style dive bar, this is not it. Bartender was curt. No one interacted with one another. It was a sad, awkward bar. The bathroom is totally Pittsburgh though; mismatched tiles, pink walls, and a sink propped up with metal poles. That took me back to my college days at the frat houses. Title of the bar is misleading.
author: Donielle G.

description: Great bar. Great owner. Great bartenders. A true local pub that feels like home. Right off the N Judah line so easy access to/from sober or not. Wouldn't want to drink anywhere else when I'm in San Francisco. Local company will never leave you bored. Always interesting variety of people. Can walk to restaurants so it's a great pre and post meal watering hole. Cold beer, warm people, no pretenses. Come as you are. Any mood. Any time. It's a comfy unpretentious local pub.
author: Z K.

description: Decent watering hole. This place used to be a real dump, but the clientele has improved a bit in recent years. Good for shooting pool.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Shortly after moving to San Francisco, I was trudging along Judah, walking to the N stop, when I looked up and saw a black and gold sign bearing "Pittsburgh's Pub." I thought I was homesick and hallucinating -- Pittsburgh, here? A little piece of home in the middle of the Outer Sunset? YES, PLEASE. We went in and sat at the bar -- it was late afternoon and not crowded; we were among regulars, who were friendly -- we struck up interesting conversations and even took another patron's dog for a walk around the block. I enjoyed chatting with Dan, the owner, who happened to be bartending -- he was very kind and entertaining.

Though the name alone was enough to draw me in, I love this place because it reminds me so much of bars where I went to college: uncomplicated, authentic dive bars. The drinks are strong and inexpensive, and there are old school games and pinball machines -- you can't beat that! Best of all, there is ZERO pretension, which is so refreshing. I highly recommend it, whether you're a transplanted yinzer or just looking to have fun.
author: Katie M.

description:
This isn't your hip mission dive bar. This is locals sitting around in the daylight drinking beer and talkin' $hit, and there's nothing wrong with that at all. If you don't like it, don't come here.

Anyone on here who is complaining about a rude-bartender or divey bar isn't the type of person you would want at Pittsburgh's Pub anyway.

It's the pittsburgh memorabilia that reminds me of my cabin in pittsburgh that i go to every summer. it's the cheap drinks and the pool tables and the loud rock music and the sports games on the big screen. It's the no-thrills-real-deal.

Sometimes it's exactly what you need.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Aaron C had a few good points -  yes, it's an honest-to-goodness DIVE BAR. I lost count at how many times that was mentioned. Are you sure, Aaron? Because you didn't sound sure... ; )   Also, that you should rate something upon what it is, not comparing it to swishier, swankier bars in town. Head to the Marina, Financial, Pac Heights or Hayes if that's the experience you're seeking. Don't be surprised when you're swimming in douche-bags. Don't get me wrong; some people like douche-bags, finding them quite date-able. I sometimes visit to these places to reinforce that I'm on the right track with my personal lifestyle choices, but now I digress...

Many reviews peg this place as "the best Dive Bar", and this, it is. This is the bar that bartenders go to when they're off. Drinks are cheap.
There a couple of bartenders who are very cool, friendly and have serious skills. Rick (long dark hair, pulled back, big guy) is a Star. I can't recall the other guy's name (Mike?). When they're bartending, by all means, come in, come in. If the place is packed, as it often is from 11p on, those two are probably the reason.

Kelly the bartender is a train wreck. She's incredibly (possibly deliberately) slow, occasionally rude and since bartenders are responsible for cleaning the restrooms, my guess is that she skips it. Does she have a good heart? Yes. But would she make a better bartender in Alaska? Definitely.

There's an older bartender who is an even messier train wreck. I've never felt so much resentment coming from a bartender for simply ordering. I don't drink Mojito's, either. I drink shots, vodka sodas, or beer and I tip crazily to half-decent bartenders. I bellied up on a Sunday at 4p with a friend for a beer. He glared at us, and finally took our order. Two beers, two shots. I thought he was going to throw them at us. I can't believe this guy has a job. I'd never stiffed a bartender in my life, until then. My friend & I drank up and headed to Tee-Off to finish drinking and yapping. 

Here's where I respectfully disagree with other reviews:

DIVE BAR does not equate to, or JUSTIFY RUDE BEHAVIOR by the bartender. Period. Ever. When I am spending my hard-earned cash at your place, I'm tipping well, am not being loud or disorderly, am keeping it simple and holding my liquor, I expect the SAME RESPECT that I am giving. There are tons of great dive bars in this city WITH friendly bartenders. It's not oil & water. It works! If you enjoy being abused, go to Zeitgeist. Some people like abuse. Just like some prefer bars full of douche-bags. 

They have two pinball machines which rates highly for me (one is full of magnets, the fishing game, a total "cheater" - the other is great and I never visit "Pitts" without a roll of quarters).

No pop on the jukebox, but you will find The Persuasions and The Temptations, vintage day rock, a little something for most... 

The crowd is older, younger, hottie, ridden-hard, hip, not hip, and just a good mix. I love a bar where I can chat with a drunken stranger over the age of 50 on my left, AND talk shop on Lady Gaga with a young gay man to my right.

The drinking crowd knows this neighborhood. It's Pitts, Hockey Haven, Tee-Off, Trader Sam's, or nothing at all.
author: S S.

description: A totally chill 'dive' that real people hang out at. I know, that's a shock for SF! The real reason I wanted to write the review is because I read that they don't like dogs. That's a darn dirty lie. I have been here with a few dogs and all the bartenders- they are totally dog friendly! Great place to unwind with neighborhood folks. I've been coming here for 6 months and feel like I can say this- if someone was 'rude' to you, it's probably cos you are a jerk. Simple as that.
author: CJ P.

description: The older lady bar tending Friday night tonight is very rude, firstly got my beer order wrong, secondly witnessed her complete over reaction to service dogs-- they had their documents! Will never come here again.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Ok, this is ridiculous folks. Learn how to review something within the parameters of what something actually is, not what you think it should be, your dream fantasy, or something completely not on the radar.

Pittsburgh's is a dive bar, DIVE BAR, not lounge, club, martini bar, Irish pub, restaurant bar, cabana, your living room, etc., etc...

That being said here are some snippets of  the "bad" reviews of this dive bar with commentary and corrections:

"Kelly is the absolute worst bartender on the planet!
Do not, I repeat, DO NOT go to this bar on Friday, Saturday, or whenever she is working!  She will not only ignore you for a good bit when you first get there, at the end of the night she will not serve you past 1:30am even if all you want is a 1 ounce shot.
She ruined it for me.  She's lazy.  Wouldn't make a drink that requires a shaker and ice.  Doesn't want to do dishes or something.  Basic lazy behavior."

Bad or rude bartender in a dive bar part of the dive bar experience, CHECK! 

How much do you think these people make, and are they really required to give a crap about you and your drunken demands at 1:30 in the morning? They work in a DIVE BAR so they don't need an excuse, unlike the current crop of airline service people. Obviously you've never been anywhere in the Mission you would have liked either. Try TGI Fridays, or Flingers, etc. for service the way you like it.

NEXT!

"Yeah this place has pool tables, pinball and microwaved hot dogs, but its brightly lit with fluorescent bulbs and has little discerning character."

Oh and you forgot to mention the standard classic rock jukebox, and cheesy beer signs. STANDARD FARE FOR A DIVE BAR!
CHECK!

Go to that dorky pirate bar over in Hayes Valley if you like themes and waterfalls with cool lights, this is a DIVE BAR BUDDY, the character here is drinking!

NEXT!

"always an older crowd there...  good place to go for a quite drink or if you don't wanna do anything but get pissed and yap with buddies...  they have a pool table there, few different other games too so thats...  for the locations though it rarely gets to many folks or at least younger folks... "

Yes they actually have darts too, and I admit that's a little luxurious for a dive bar. But really, two stars for a place to "get pissed and yap with buddies"? What are you supposed to do in a DIVE BAR???? Or ANY bar for that matter? Maybe they have roller coasters in the bars where you come from? In any case I don't want to see the results of that....

Yes, it's a real dive bar where you go drinking, a LOT. Yapping is not required. CHECK! NEXT!

"I don't know.  when you're going to school at 7:30am and see people waiting at the front to get in for "first call," you begin to ask some questions."

Alcoholics usually go to DIVE BARS to get drunk, that's why they are called DIVE BARS. In order to not sober up and start seeing stuff that isn't there they need to start drinking early. This place caters to dive bar patrons surprisingly enough because it is a DIVE BAR! CHECK!! NEXT!!!

"Am I retarded for thinking this place would have anything to do with Pittsburgh? I wanted to like this place. Wanted to love it. I went in with the lowest of the low of expectations."

Lowest expectations eh? Lowest expectations are what you get in a dive bar pal because they are not built for expectations other than getting drunk. Sounds like you need to join your friend above at that pirate bar I mentioned. Don't they have some crap baseball team called that from the same city you want your theme to be in? Might be perfect for you. NEXT!

Oh boy, the list goes on and on......
But lastly, to make sure and cover all the basics of a dive bar:

"BTW, the mens room is horrific and, based on 3 inquiries,  the ladies room isn't much better ."

Ummm, I have yet to be in a real dive bar that has sweet smelling, clean bathrooms. I mean they drop those chemical bombs in the water that permeate your clothing for days after like every other dive bar does. But still, part of the experience of going to your local dive is to see how long you can hold your breath in the bathroom, or just breath through your mouth like experienced drinkers do. Piss quickly and leave, do number two before you go out!

Stinky old bathroom part of the dive bar formula? FINAL CHECK!

Have fun at Pittsburgh's, it's a dying breed, literally. 
And always remember, "Don't Try"....
author: Aaron C.

description: I've been known to drink here. Ding two stars for me always being so hungover but I'll give one back for the kickass Bloody Marys.
author: Lance G.

description:
How can anyone who reads these reviews, or even sees this place from the street be the least bit surprised about how dive-y it is?

Can a place be too dive-y?
Maybe.
I'm OK with dive-y, but I draw the line at fight-y.
This place is just plain dive-y and that's just fine.

A few visits proved it to be fun and interesting.  Everyone was there for a good time, some drunker than the rest, but everyone seemed friendly.  Never a dull moment, that's for sure.

I'm OK with the fact that the entire bathroom smells like the inside of a toilet.  That's why it's called "the can."  As long as someone is sanitizing the bar-ware...

On the plus side, the drinks are VERY affordable, the several bartenders I met were all amiable, they've got Powers, and they have the Dead on the jukebox.

Add a couple of pool tables, some pinball and a dart board, what else could one want?

Dontcha go changin', Pitts!
author: Ken B.

description:
"You're home!" you excitedly exclaim, as your roommate walks through the front door. You put on your oven mitts and grab the homemade lasagna you have been baking all day.

"Look, we need to talk," he tells you.

"Oh we can talk later, let's eat dinner!" you say, nodding to the dining room table.

"I'm leaving you," he says, coldly. "I'm leaving you for another room."

The sound of the glass casserole dish shattering on the kitchen floor snaps you back to reality. You stand there, in shock, unable to say anything.

"Look, I can't stay long, my new rooms waiting on me," he says. "The papers are signed, everything is finalized." You stare at him, still unable to form words. "I'm sorry it turned out this way, it's just that this new place is a lot younger, it likes to have a lot of bars around it...it just makes me feel something that this room hasn't made me feel in a long time."

He hands you his set of keys and walks out the door.

You've heard the old adage that the best way to get over someone is to get under someone, so you want to get someone under that room's roof as soon as possible. You'll go to Pittsburghs Pub nightly, looking for anyone alive and breathing to take home and show off that room to. You're in such despair and getting so drunk because of the heavy shots they pour at Pittburghs that you won't remember half the people you bring home to show the room to. There will be many mornings when you wake up to some random stranger sleeping next door in the available room. They'll give you their number, and tell you to call them because they are interested in the room, but you won't. After a few weeks, you'll find a potential roommate and they'll stick around for a few weeks. Things will be going great, until one day you come home from work and find them sitting on the couch.

"You're not supposed to SIT on the couch," you'll find yourself screaming. "You're supposed to lay there, LAY there like a fucking cat!" you yell, and that will be the end of that roommate.

You'll keep going back to Pittburghs, because it's such an awesome bar with darts and pool tables and they serve your signature drink, The Hurtin' Bomb, but you'll no longer feel the need to bring people back to check out the room. You'll realize, that to really move on, you have to get as far away from the Outer Sunset as you can. Maybe back to the Mission, you ponder to yourself after your third Hurtin' Bomb...
author: Dave G.

description:
Popped in here on the way back to the city on New Year's Eve. We had come out to the ocean, taken some pictures, saw the sun sliding into the sea as the year went with it. The place looked divey enough to meet our standards for a jump-off point for the night, and it served this purpose well.

Dank, empty and dusty at this juncture, I can only imagine the clientelle that this place draws in less well lit hours. I'm thinking old men, mostly, and then I think pirate accents, and no, this is not a shanty of that sort. This place is the beach bum cousin of the more inner city dive bars. You know, it's a little funky, and just as bad, but you only see it now and then, and no one at the other dives talks about it, except in passing. It's not a bad bar, it's just that it lives so far away, and well, you know what happened with Aunt Louis and the twins...
author: Wes T.

description: My favorite local pub! It's a great place to end your night if you are a local. It has a very classic dive bar feel. It's like the cheers of the outer sunset. I love this place!
author: Flatulent B.

description: I love a good dive.  No offense.  This place is a blast and pours a good stiff drink.  Start making your juke box selection right when you get there!
author: Susie Q.

description:
Stop 2 along the N Judah Pub Crawl landed us at Pittsburgh's Pub.

Extremely unassuming, this corner pub while completely uninviting from the front, was a welcome gift along the crawl.

The music scratched to a halt as the 4 of us stepped inside, and as the cold glances of the regulars shot through us, we claimed the bar as ours, and all was alright... 

In truth, we had a blast here. Kelly, the bartender, was amazing and we quickly made friends with the men who were growing roots on the bar stools as they were simply permanent fixtures.

With a pool table, pin ball machine, a great juke box, video games and darts, this was the framework for what later became Dave and Busters.

As we celebrated for Friday's sake, we made good friends, enjoyed a pint or 2 and left with some fantastic memories to put in the SF bank.

Cheers Pittsburgh, we'll be back!
author: Mike K.

description:
I am in disbelief that this place is rated so high. I really am. I don't know one person that likes going to this bar, and I live in the Sunset. I actually used to live two blocks away, wanted to call it my local, but went there a few times and decided never again. Never, ever again.

The place is dirty, the bathrooms are gross with no lock on the door (I am a chick, so a dude probably doesn't care about that fact, but the kind of guys that hang out in that bar, a lock is the order of the day), and two out of three bartenders were rude and not responsive. Another thing a dude doesn't care about are the old guys that will crowd you when you are left unattended. My boyfriend and his friend went out for a smoke, my friend and I stayed seated. Two regulars took their seats immediately to hit on us. We mentioned that our boyfriends were outside, and they laughed and said they'd get up when the men-folk came back. They just wanted a chat. That situation was repeated on future visits. 

The bar just gives me a bad vibe. Again, I am a chick, so maybe this isn't a review that helps a man any, but I do not feel safe when I go to that bar. I feel safe in the neighborhood--not a lot happens way out there--but that bar is nasty. Even if there weren't seedy people that basically live there, running a mop now and again wouldn't go amiss.
author: Katie C.

description: Great experience for a random Tuesday night! Met great people, played pool, and had a great time :D
author: Dianna C.

description: Kelly is the coolest sweetest bartender ever.
author: Chelsey G.

description: This place makes me feel like I'm back in Iowa, in college and about to make a bad decision.
author: Angelina C.

description: I love this spot. It's a local spot. I LOVE the bartenders and everyone I met was great. Cash only but ATM inside. Corner table is now our hang out spot.
author: Nathan O.

description:
If only I could write a review on the staff alone. Ray is the best, and Dan never ceases to make me laugh (ask him about the banana split and to show and tell about the photo behind the bar.....hes quite the interesting storyteller).

Unfortunately for them, or fortunately, depending how many dive bar conniseuers read this, I have strange stories of drunken men saying even stranger things to me when I am here. This is somewhere I will only go if accompanied by more than one person, and if I get a full inventory of who is already there before I walk into the place.

I have been yelled at, more than once, by the regular patrons here. This is a good time to mention that, I have heard, a few of these same individuals have been arrested for unruly behavior since my run ins with them. I've witnessed fights, near fights, lovefests and people passing out cold at the bar....all signs of a good dive bar, right?

The thing that really tops it off for me is the memory of the time I was asked if I was a call girl, and the man was dead serious. What makes this even better is that it was 6PM and I was wearing a business suit, having just gotten off of one of those long days where the bigwigs were coming and I had to dress professionally. Not THAT sort of profession - but, hey guy, thanks for asking!
author: Drue C.

description:
i love this bar! not because i live 10 seconds away and not because i share the same name with one of the bartenders..its cheap, has a nice "homey-divey" feel, it has a dart board, 2 pool tables, pinball machine and a jukebox! most patrons are neighborhood regulars but everyone is welcomed. 

cash only! but theres an atm inside. :)
author: Kelly K.

description:
This place terrifies me, but in a good way.  Better than the Silver Spur, this place has serious character.  And by character, I mean there is none.  For all you know, you were never drinking shitty whiskey in San Francisco.  The place is too bright, the pool tables are shitty, and it's freezing because it's right next to the damn ocean.  Imagine Clooney's on 25th and Valencia but not in such a good location.  Read my review on Clooney's, dammit.

To sum it up:  Too cold, too far out of the way, too bright, no character, creepy ocean/Sunset people.
author: Meh M.

description: Love this bar and all evening bartenders. Always have a good time. Cheap drinks and very cool people.  All thumbs up!!
author: Kat S.

description:
OUTER Sunset. Not sorta kinda...Pittsburgh's Pub is in B. effin' E. After some thought, I realized it's actually the westernmost dive in San Francisco. And that's about all it is.

It's a classic dive bar--jukebox, pool tables, random photographs and outdated stickers strewn about. Mismatched chairs, stools & people haunt this bar...giving it a 'i don't know what to think' feeling. 

There was a drunk dude who actually ended up breaking up a cat fight and kicking some other guy out of the bar, simply stating "You aren't wanted here, we don't appreciate that...". The dude left! I recognized him, he's a fellow Yelper. 

:::thumbs up:::

Oh, and there's obnoxious hit on every woman simultaneously guy...He's a riot to watch.

They have Anchor Steam on draft = 1 star
Far West Bar named back East = 1 star
Yelper Dude who keeps it cool = 1 star

Not my type of spot but try it out for what it's worth.
author: matt m.

description:
Like most drinking establishments that hail from the Outer Sunset, Pittsburgh's Pub is pretty rough around the edges.  But unlike a lot of them, it's got a lot more going for it.  Amongst these things are many intangible qualities....qualities such as character, local charm, and community. Want to know the odds on the favorite horse running in the third race at Bay meadows?  Ask the gray haired man speaking loudly in an Irish accent.  Curious about when somebody from the hood is due to be in court or to get out of prison?  Talk to the guy missing a tooth at the end of the bar.  Need to know the point spread for this weekends Steeler game?  Talk to Pittsburgh Dan, a born and bred Pittsburgh native that made his way Westward to run Pittsburgh's pub for better or for worse...

The crowd is fairly static.  This is due to a sociological phenomenon observable in the Sunset and the Richmond...one where the Avenues function something like a sieve of humanity, gradually screening out the tourists, wannabes, and bridge-and-tunnel posers as you head West and the numbers get bigger.  Most of them come straight off the bridge and make a beeline up to North Beach.  The next big chunk gets hung up at 9th and Irving, then 19th Ave screens out most of what's left.  By the time you're out to 47th and Judah, anything that isn't lived-here-for-years local or westward-with-a-destination gets pretty much filtered out.  The few that make it this far out don't give Pittsburgh's a second glance as they high-tail it out  to Ocean Beach.  The result is a VERY local crowd....a crowd that's tight-knit, but not insular....a clientele that isn't afraid to say who they are, and never claims to be anything they're not.   You won't get a warm welcome just for walking in the door, but you'll probably get a handshake and a smile if you make the first effort to break the ice.  
    
From a square-footage standpoint, Pittsburgh's is pretty large for an outer Sunset pub.  The Judah street entrance dumps you right at the point of a shotgun bar that runs the length of the West wall.  A spacious area towards the Southeast corner hosts dueling pool tables.  A sizable dart throwing area takes up the remainder of the space with four boards on the Judah street wall. 

There's usually a seat at the bar, though it can fill up after work or on weekend nights. The crowd for sporting events rarely makes a dent in available seating , though Steeler games during football season tend to fill the bar,  forcing overflow seating into an awkward arrangement in the pool/dart area.   Eat before you head out here...There's no kitchen on the premises, the restaurant selection is pretty bleak, and free bar snacks only come once in a blue moon. ( Update 6-24-06 There's a great Chinese take-out place just up the street ) The dart boards get plenty of action after dark, but  pool tables usually go begging.  The premises have a pleasant mustiness about them without being dirty, and the bathrooms are always clean.

If you're looking for a neighborhood hangout in the Outer Sunset, give Pittsburgh's a good looking over.  Ditto that if you live somewhere else, and you're in search of a home-away-from-home.  The patrons are real, the owner is friendly, and the N-Judah MUNI makes a stop within a stones throw of the front door...
author: Mike W.

description:
It's a beer and shots bar.  They will have the game on and they got some ok TV's.   There's pool and decent music on the box.  The regulars are all right type folks and they pour a proper shot.  What more do you want?

Oh and Dan, the owner is top notch.
author: J K.

description:
I have lived only 3 blocks from this place my entire life and always walk past it. When I was younger, this place just seemed like a hangout for patrons needing their fix at about 10 am. Pretty gnarly. Now, older, I occasional venture in for a pint or two...or three or four. The prices are very reasonable, the beer selection is decent, the shots are cheap. 
Every time I go to this bar with some pals, I'm sure we are the youngest ones there. I'm for it though. It is really fun to talk to the people there and the bartenders, despite some what intimating, are quite friendly. The patrons have never given me any problems or anything...one guy even bought us drinks for relating stories haha.
Location wise is awesome. I mean, even though I only live a few blocks up, my pals easily get here with the N or the 18.
author: Zach L.

description:
Actually, they do care if you puff weed outside, and won't bother to remember you even after seven months except as "that asshole who burns weed and then expects a drink. Fuck that guy." 

If not you, they will, at least, remember your womenfolk. Uh, thanks? 

And of all the pool cues in the place I've found one that's not bent to shit. Real men use fists, not sticks.
author: Chris R.

description:
Now this is a drinkers bar. 
Glad it's so close to my house. 
Great location, great selection of beer on tap, cool bartenders and very down to earth atmosphere.
They are only closed during prohibition hours from 2AM to 6AM. 
Otherwise, they are open for business all the time.
author: Larry J.

description:
I thinks everyone's covered everything... 

Ray and Kelly are great bartenders!
author: Andrew E.

description:
There are dive bars and then there is this place!

Thought it would be a an easy local to go to for a few pints and a game of pool -  how wrong were we!

Took a group of 10 friends for a drink after dinner one night - will NEVER GO BACK!
The barmaid was so rude, we were practically kicked out at 1.30 (despite drinking up not finishing until 2am) while everyone else sat happily finishing their drinks in peace.  When we commented (didn't argue) that we were the only ones being asked to finish up and there was still nearly a half hour left - I was told 'not to be an a - hole' and 'don't bother coming back here' - well, I'll not need to be asked twice!
author: Aimee W.

description: Cash only, although they do have an ATM. I looked at the crowd and decided it would be better to just order a beer. I don't know if she could handle a cocktail? Interesting area over there. Hipsters, choose-to-be bums, and tourists. Some good people too. :-P
author: Chris I.

description:
Sitting in a hotel bar in Pittsburgh inspires me to write a review about this place.  Sadly, it does not have IC, Yuengling, or even a nice spread of marinated kielbasa for younze, but it's a fine dive bar on the beach that captures a bit of the culture of the old Rust Belt, East Coast vibe.

My special moment here was a warm night a few years ago, when the official harassment at Ocean Beach was winding up toward the current pseudo-post-9/11 security theatre. Escaping for friendlier scenes, we wandered to Pittsburgh's and had a nice night at the bar. But as we arrived, a birthday party was ending, and they left behind the carcass of a whole roast pig.  Actually, just the head, more or less. After a few rounds, one of our group couldn't resist the comic possibilities. There's nothinq quite like feeling a tap on the shoulder and turning to greet the grinning detached head of a porcine brother. It's even better when it chases you around the bar making "Sooooeeeeeeee!" noises.  

Hmm. I think this sort of thing got us 86ed.  Fair.
author: Matt R.

description:
So, my friend got me this awesome mug for Christmas, nevermind what it said because many may judge, but in any case he gave it to me on the Muni ride to this bar (which, from my house, is quite the trek). Anyways, this naturally means I need to use said mug to drink beer out of when I get to the bar, being the classy lady that I am. I proceed to stupidly leave my mug behind and only remember halfway through the painfully long Muni ride home. Needless to say, the awesome bartender kept it for me behind the bar until I was able to retrieve it a couple weeks later and even let me know that she had been showing it to all her customers, who got quite the kick out of it. 

Ok place overall, always open pool tables which is great but a little to far from home without delivering massively good times for my tastes. Always friendly service though, which is a lot in this city.
author: sholeh m.

description:
This bar has to be my favorite in the city. It (usually) has a warm and friendly atmosphere that you can really only get from a place located in the Outer Sunset. While most of the business is local (either people who live near Ocean Beach, or work out here), there are random days when a large pile of people will appear out of nowhere and give us all something to talk about besides how drunk we get. Some people say that they are intimidated to go into the bar the first time, but seriously don't be a pathetic wus.

The day times are pretty mellow, but entertaining nonetheless. If you somehow end up hungover at 8am in the Outer Sunset, this is the place you want to come to cure your hangover while you wait for a N-Judah rush hour to pass.

If you just had your bonfire shut down by the feddies at midnight (or they stole all your beer), this is the place to come to enjoy the rest of the night.

If it's 1 in the afternoon and you know that the day is already a wash and it's time to start drinking early, it's worth a visit to the Outer Sunset. 

The bar is extremely friendly to new customers, outside food, and to chain smokers out front.

Advice for Newbies: The bar gets very busy socially, and the bartenders are very very nice people, so cut them a break when you're ordering (order shots in groups not individually, return your glasses to the bar, don't whine if the bartender is out front smoking). A little courtesy goes a long way in this party  town.
author: Snaker Z.

description: 2 pool tables, alcohol, and DARTS! Everything you need for an inexpensive-yet-still-fun time.
author: Nelson S.

description:
I can handle just about any bar.  Anytime.

This place is just to rough for me.  People here are looking for a fight.  It reminds me of being in a bar in Sacramento.  Come to think of it, it reminds me of the last bar I was at in Pitt also. Way to go!

BTW, props to "Max E." who said, "remember you could be talking to some jackass in the Marina about his car."  I really couldn't agree more.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Good local bar.  

Being from Pittsburgh, I was drawn in because of the name -- crossing my fingers and hoping a cold IC Light draft and some other transplanted yinzers might wait behind that half-door.  I was disappointed not to find any imported IC Light or Penn Pilsner or even Yueingling, but the black-and-gold paraphernalia on the walls and the overall, slightly faded feeling almost made me think I was back at home in the rust belt, and so did the civil, but not-too-friendly patrons lining the bar.  

Just how I like it.
author: Megan D.

description:
I took some folks from out of town here,who are big barflies,and they loved it.Pool table,check.Scary old men sitting at the bar,check.Reasonably priced drinks,check. Great jukebox,even with The Mermen on it,check! 
  There is a great woman bartender named Kelly that works there. I wish more girls would come and hang out,but ya,all those guys over 60 freak some people out.
Not a place to meet the man of your dreams...
author: Nan H.

description:
Can a dive bar feel homey? Is it the first sign of alcoholism?? 

This place is cozy and tiny but not in way-too-many-people-can't-breathe way. They have a pool table, darts, and a juke box. The seating is pretty limited but I'm usually able to find a spot away from the bar just fine (too many old men at the bar, haha). Also a wide collection of used appliances is collecting dust by the front door - very sunset.
author: Tatyana K.

description:
oh goddamn!  where to begin??? this place is THE dive bar of dive bars.  i mean, this place is so depressing they give you prozac with your drinks.  i happened to stumble upon this place by pure happenstance several weeks ago after eating at sri thai (not that great btw, but that's for another yelp review) over on lincoln.  we were in the mood to grab a drink so we walked over to judah to find a spot and the first place we see is pittsburghs.  let's just say that upon first glance pittsburghs was not at the top of our list.  but after walking up judah a few blocks and finding nothing in sight we decided to take our chances.  

let me just say that my friend is from wisconsin and i'm originally from iowa, so when we walked into pittsburghs our first thought was something along the lines of, "wow, this reminds me of a bar back home!"  yup, it's THAT bad.  this is the kind of place that mission hipsters would dig if they were to ever venture out of the mission.  this is the kind of place where people order PBR because they've actually been drinking PBR since the days when PBR commercials went, "what'll ya have?  pabst blue ribbon..."  i'm not kidding, there are some serious characters in this joint.  i have no doubt that if i rolled over there right now i'd probably run into some of them again.  there was one lady there that was just puttin it down!!!  i don't know what she was drinking, but i'll just call it the three bears because it was a shot of something dark.  with a chaser of something dark and it wasn't coke cuz there weren't any bubbles in that glass so you know it was hard stuff.  followed by a pint of brew.  she must have gone through 3 rounds of that in the hour and a half we were there.  then there's the super drunk dude at the bar that was trying to mack some asian cougar lady for about an hour.  up until some lady walks in carrying her 2 year old daughter saying, "i'm lookin fer mah husband!!!" to which he strolls over to his baby mama and leaves the place.  we're talking people that are serious about getting their drizzank on!!!

but that's what makes this place awesome.  it is what it is.  a crappy bar, with people that drink...a lot.  i give this thing a full five stars for staying true to the game!  this is what wannabe trendy dive bars aspire to be.
author: D L.

description:
all kinds of love for abe and kelly!! it's a neighborhood bar. good times

if you had a problem with kelly then i blame you. when i lived out there she would say hi to me as i walked in the door. she would also douche bag guard me. 

it's a local place, laid back vibe. calm down/get over yourself.

abe is awesome
author: kiki b.

description:
"I've never been to Pittsburgh, but I think they got it right."

What more can I say?  On the downside, it's so dark in there it makes the perpetual fog of the outer sunset seem blinding upon reemergence.  And we're talking depressing hide-your-drunk-a$$-in-the-corner dark, take-me-home-and-regret-it dark, not sultry subdued dark.  On the upside, they have two kinds of anchor steam (which any great SF pub should, so I'm not THAT impressed).

On Bay to Breakers Day it was all piss-drunk locals at 11am until the slowpokes caught up.  At which point everyone seemed confused.
author: Jennifer B.

description: If Flanahan's is where souls go to die, this is their purgatory.
author: Kevin K.

description: Total dive bar. Scene is awesome. There are some regulars I try to avoid talking to but the bartenders are very, very good. Prices are very fair. I highly recommend this place.
author: B K.

description: Not really sure how we stumbled into here after the last bay to breakers as by then everything was already pretty hazy.  The one thing I do remember was Pittsburgh Dan (I think?) pouring some of the best bloody mary's I've ever had.  Well done good sir, I hope to be back one day.
author: David L.

description: Just moved from the inner to the outer set. Needed a new local dive. The Pitt is The Place. Juke box, decent TVs, two pool tables and some video games. Also, Abe the bartender is great. Always takes care of you regardless. Now I just need to convince them to start a shuttle service for the local area.... 8 blocks is really far at 2am...
author: Parker H.

description: Great place. Fun times fun people, strong drinks. Best local in town. Dans the man , kellys a diamond, Bob don't take no BS and Abes a gent.
author: Julian P.

description: Honestly, not that lively of a bunch but defiantly a place you can count on to be by the beach and open in the morning for any of your drink wishes.  I wished for an Anchor Steam, big surprise, but it was a new keg, so it took for ever to poor a cup, eventually he gave me the 1st one that was not full and gave me another one later... I was happy... 2 almost full beers for the price of one.
author: Megan L.

description: Perfect neighborhood dive-- walkable, great juke box, pool, darts, pinball, cash only (keeps you in check and alleviates extra spending), great staff, solid crowd. If you live anywhere East of Chain of Lakes drive and need to add a new neighborhood haunt to your roster of bars, add this one. You will not be sorry. Bomb it with a crew of friend or alone, you'll totally make new friends.
author: Brandi S.

description: the PITT. 5 blocks from the house, kelly let's us have a couple on the house (my exchange is sometimes cheese), good beer selection, pool table, jukebox always playing, theater of magic pin ball (bf's favorite), and cally is allowed in with us- kept on leash..that she drags around (only when kelly's working!) and she has secret treats and cally knows every time she heads in there, go to the bar side, sit, and treats galore! sometimes sketchy characters there.. who happen to think they are all bad and tough and trying to start fights with a whiskey drunk guy. not cool. but the bar is good, and local.
author: Abigail W.

description:
First off, I have to agree with Mike W who said "This is due to a sociological phenomenon observable in the Sunset and the Richmond...one where the Avenues function something like a sieve of humanity, gradually screening out the tourists, wannabes, and bridge-and-tunnel posers as you head West and the numbers get bigger."  Nothing could better describe the Outer Sunset and the resulting crowd that this bar has to offer.  It's right around the corner from my house and to be honest, if there was some posh drinking space in it's place, I'd happily call that my local bar as well.  I'm just lucky that the Pittsburgh is here instead.  

Most dive bars have some irony about them.  Bartenders that act mean on purpose, unclean bathrooms as a sort of indicator that you are truly in a dive bar, and almost always, some random piece of junk such as an old dead car *cough Zeitgeist!* to give it that feel.  This is the real deal - walk inside and you feel like you're in a mining town in Allegheny County.  Plenty of space to stretch out and chill with your friends, and literally no need to pose or try to impress a soul.  Just come here, get a drink, relax and feel at home.  Plenty of things could change - they could add to the beer selection, add a kitchen, whatever, but I say the formula works, why change it.

There's several screens with different games on so you won't miss a thing.  If you do, just ask Dan, he will give you the details.  The last time I was there, he gave me my last few drinks free.  "Been buyin' booze all night, this one's on the house" is what he said.  Show me another bar in SF where they even give a crap.
author: Mr. A.

description: You have to know what you are getting into: local bar, no frills, pretty good pinball, pool and darts. Ray the bartender is a local institution, as are a few of the regulars. Drop your pretensions at the door, hang out with some cops, musicians, local wait staff, and the hippy fringe of the outer sunset. Guzzle your Kesslers and remember you could be talking to some jackass in the Marina about his car. Rinse, wash, repeat.
author: Max E.

description: Yeah this place has pool tables, pinball and microwaved hot dogs, but its brightly lit with fluorescent bulbs and has little discerning character.
author: Rick H.

description: This place is off and on.. either way, it's always fun to go with your friends if you live in the area.  They got pool and a pretty good selection of beers. yeeeah gotta love THE PITT!!!
author: Antonia R.

description: Came out here with some friends last night not knowing what to expect.  What I found was a classic middle America feeling local bar.  The place seems to attract normal middle aged blue collar folk.  The bartender (and everyone else for that matter) was nice and in good spirits, the pours were heavy, there's pinball, pool tables, and darts, and the place is totally removed from any "scene" you might find in the city.  Once inside you could be in any small town neighborhood bar in the country for all you know.   This seems like a great place to escape when you get your fill of the whole trendy San Francisco vibe common in bars deeper into the city.  I'll be back.
author: Joshua W.

description: Living in OB, this is the creme de la creme of dive bars to rock. $4 Ketel & tonics, what more do I need to say.
author: j d.

description: I was afraid of this place.  It had a couple of strikes against it.  One, it's waaayyy out by Ocean Beach, and before you outer sunset-ites get grumpy about me badmouthing the neighborhood, it just gets a little scary and foggy at night is all.  Two, there always seem to be...interesting looking women hanging around outside this place.  Anyway, probably because I already was fueled by alcohol, I checked out this place and I will just say one thing: chocolate cake in a shot glass.  Now, the bartender convinced me that Frangelico and vanilla vodka chased with a sugary lemon tastes just like chocolate cake and I was all, "nuh UH" but it was a very drunk girl's birthday so we joined in.  Well my friends, it tasted like chocolate cake!  And for anyone that knows me, chocolate cake is my kryptonite.  Finding it in (highly) alcoholic form is very, very dangerous.
author: Leslie R.

description: I'm from Pittsburgh, visiting San Francisco and looking for a Steeler's bar for Sunday's (Jan. 23rd) game. This place sounds like a classic - but is there a real Pitt connection or is it just in name only?
author: molly a.

description: In the outer sunset, when you go to the Pittsburgh's Pub, you're going to "The Pit." You can find all kinds of people in there sippin on jack and throwing back beers. The jukebox has great classic rock music, and you never have to wait for pool or darts. Sometimes the crowd can be a bit shady, but overall it's a classic local, dirty, low class bar.....and I love it!
author: Nikka B.

description:
This place is one of my homes away from home...and thank God I can stumble home to my main home after visiting this home.

Ray and Kelly are excellent barkeeps!  And Pittsburgh Dan - well - he's quite simply tha man!   

 Though he'll try and get ya drunk if he takes a shine to ya.

Yea - it can seem rough around the edges but if you're a nice person, you're welcome. If you're not, that will become apparent soon enough and hopefully you'll be ejected never to return cause we don't need your kind around here buddy boy that's right don't make us call the cops on ya hey Ray gimme another bourbon um dude you're in my seat thanks.

Fun place. Good Times. Great Memories.

Um...the bathrooms could be cleaner. Just sayin'...
author: L'Manda K.

description: It's a local place- no frills- but they have a good juke box, a decent selection of beer on tap, good prices and it's easy to find people to play a game of pool or darts.  The bartenders are friendly and get to know who you are in a couple of visits and the regulars have great stories to tell.  It's a great jeans and t-shirt bar.
author: M. S.

description: Its a bar, its next to my house, they don't take credit cards, and anytime i have ever walked past, or been there, there is a an old guy with a big white beard. - Perfect
author: Thomas W.

description: Great neighborhood dive bar.  I like the bartender, the people and the drinks that are reasonably priced.  Parking is easy.  Drinks at Pittsburgh, dinner at Thank Long, nightcab at Pittsburgh!  Works for me.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
from what i have observed, if you need to break up with your old ball and chain then the Pitt is the bar for you. just get there early. i live around the corner and walk past it almost every morning and i have seen at least three couples departing and breaking up on the side walk before 8:30 am. 

my man and i had a house warming party that ended at the Pitt. our friends from out of town were shocked by the decore and by the end of the night my man had been removed from the premises for drinking a 40 outside. the next night his face was instantly forgotten and we took this as a good sign and have been sweet on the old shack since. 

a couple of weeks ago we lost our dog and they let us post our fliers inside. when we went back to take them down, beaming with dog in tow, the packed bar broke into applauds and congratulations.  it was before noon.
author: Maggie Baggie H.

description: There are very few bars that don't host amateur hour all day every day. Pittsburgh's may not be the classiest place in town, but it is one of the few places you can go to avoid the nonsense. The bartenders are outstanding and the regulars are super friendly. Two pool tables, dartboard, fireplace, whiskey and jager. I'm sold.
author: D. A.

description: always an older crowd there...  good place to go for a quite drink or if you don't wanna do anything but get pissed and yap with buddies...  they have a pool table there, few different other games too so thats...  for the locations though it rarely gets to many folks or at least younger folks...  cool enough spot though...
author: Anthony Z.
